P.title: Will human brain emulation be the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if an effort to create a viable (functioning, lasting, sane, etc.) emulated human, based on direct simulation of the neural connectome (and a requisite level of its physical instantiation), succeeds before another form of human-level digital intelligence. The latter will be defined as a digital entity capable of equalling or surpassing most or all core human cognitive capabilities.
If neither a whole human brain emulation nor a human-level digital intelligence has been successfully demonstrated before January 1, 2060, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
*(Edit 10/20/18 to state that it resolves ambiguous rather than negative in the event of no AGI by 2060.)

Q_given_P.title: Given that human brain emulation is the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence, will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if human brain emulation is not the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence. If human brain emulation is successful before any other form of human-level digital intelligence, then resolves as per the criteria for Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040.

P_and_Q.title: Will human brain emulation be the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence AND will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if an effort to create a viable emulated human based on direct simulation of the neural connectome succeeds before another form of human-level digital intelligence AND the machine system outscores at least two of the three humans on the specified test prior to 2040. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: If chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Zermelo's theorem says that only one of three possibilities is possible in a 2-player solved game; First player (white) wins, second player (black) wins, or there is a forced draw.
In the game of chess, these outcomes correspond to:
White wins
Black wins
Forced draw
If chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning?
For the purpose of this question, chess is considered to be solved if
it is proved that white will win, lose or draw from the initial position, given perfect play on both sides
it is shown that there exists a unique result of perfect play from the initial position, which is either: white wins, black wins, or forced draw
Resolution is by publication of peer-reviewed article that is not shown to be mistaken for at least 3 years post-publication.
For the purpose of this question, the 50-move rule does not force a draw. Games that don't end, are considered drawn, for the purpose of this question
This question resolves ambiguously if the question does not resolve before Jan 1st, 2080.

Q_given_P.title: Given that chess is solved before 2080 and perfect play results in white winning, by 2025 will someone be able to hold his/her breath for 30+ minutes?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if chess is not solved before 2080 or if perfect play does not result in white winning. If the condition is met (if chess is solved before 2080 and perfect play results in white winning), then resolves YES if by 2025 someone is able to hold his/her breath for more than 30 minutes according to Guinness Record standards, and NO if not.

P_and_Q.title: If chess is solved before 2080 resulting in white winning, will someone be able to hold his/her breath for 30+ minutes by 2025?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if chess is solved before 2080 with perfect play resulting in white winning AND someone is able to hold his/her breath for 30+ minutes by 2025. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: If chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Zermelo's theorem says that only one of three possibilities is possible in a 2-player solved game; First player (white) wins, second player (black) wins, or there is a forced draw.
In the game of chess, these outcomes correspond to:
White wins
Black wins
Forced draw
If chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning?
For the purpose of this question, chess is considered to be solved if
it is proved that white will win, lose or draw from the initial position, given perfect play on both sides
it is shown that there exists a unique result of perfect play from the initial position, which is either: white wins, black wins, or forced draw
Resolution is by publication of peer-reviewed article that is not shown to be mistaken for at least 3 years post-publication.
For the purpose of this question, the 50-move rule does not force a draw. Games that don't end, are considered drawn, for the purpose of this question
This question resolves ambiguously if the question does not resolve before Jan 1st, 2080.

Q_given_P.title: Given that chess is solved before 2080 with perfect play resulting in white winning, will a sample of negative energy be produced by 2100?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if chess is not solved before 2080 with perfect play resulting in white winning. If the condition is met (if chess is solved before 2080 with perfect play resulting in white winning, then resolves YES if a sample of negative energy material will be created by the year 2100 as described and NO if it will not be created by 2100.

P_and_Q.title: If chess is solved before 2080 resulting in white winning AND a sample of negative energy is produced by 2100?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if chess is solved before 2080 with perfect play resulting in white winning AND a sample of negative energy material is created by the year 2100 as specified. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves as YES if the machine system outscores at least two of the three humans on the following test prior to 2040, or NO otherwise. If no such tests are conducted, resolves as AMBIGUOUS.
Assume that prior to 2040, a generalized intelligence test will be administered as follows. A team of three expert interviewers will interact with a candidate machine system (MS) and three humans (3H). The humans will be graduate students in each of physics, mathematics and computer science from one of the top 25 research universities (per some recognized list), chosen independently of the interviewers. The interviewers will electronically communicate (via text, image, spoken word, or other means) an identical series of exam questions of their choosing over a period of two hours to the MS and 3H, designed to advantage the 3H. Both MS and 3H have full access to the internet, but no party is allowed to consult additional humans, and we assume the MS is not an internet-accessible resource. The exam will be scored blindly by a disinterested third party.
Note that this also effectively tests whether the internet as a whole functions as a human-level intelligence, in that a positive resolution indicates that the human participants are effectively superfluous.

Q_given_P.title: Given that there will be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040, will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if there is no Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040. If the condition is met (if there is Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040), then resolves YES if by November 30, 2027, a peer-reviewed publication announces the results of such an event with statistical significance at the 4-sigma or equivalent level, and NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040 AND will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if the machine system outscores at least two of the three humans on the intelligence test AND a peer-reviewed publication announces the detection of gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes by November 30, 2027. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will humans go extinct before 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there are no known humans alive on January 1, 2100. For these purposes we'll define humans as biological creatures who have as their ancestors – via a chain of live births from mothers – circa 2000 humans OR who could mate with circa 2000 humans to produce viable offspring. (So AIs, ems, genetically engineered beings of a different species brought up in artificial wombs, etc. would not count). Any living humans living anywhere in the observable universe (or multiverse) (who are known to the entities operating Metaculus) on that date will be sufficient to resolve the question negatively.
N.B. Even though it is obviously the case that if human extinction occurs Metaculus points won't be very valuable anymore and that it will be practically impossible to check for true human extinction (zero humans left), I would like to ask people not to let this fact influence their prediction and to predict in good faith

Q_given_P.title: Given that humans go extinct before 2100, will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if humans do not go extinct before 2100. If the condition is met (if humans go extinct before 2100), then resolves YES if the first practical nuclear fusion reactor is developed in China, and NO if it is developed anywhere else.

P_and_Q.title: Will humans go extinct before 2100 AND will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if there are no known humans alive on January 1, 2100 AND the first practical nuclear fusion reactor is developed in China. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the richest person in the world in 2033 have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Data for resolution shall be taken from the 2033 Forbes Billionaires list (note: of course the link currently does not lead to the 2033 list). Note that this list is to be differentiated from the real time list.

Q_given_P.title: Given that the richest person in the world in 2033 will have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time, will we discover clear evidence of proton decay by 2040?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the condition about the richest person's net worth is not met in 2033. If the condition is met (if the richest person's net worth is equivalent to or greater than 2% of the US GDP in 2033), then resolves YES if experimental evidence for proton decay is published in a top peer-reviewed journal before 2040, and NO if not.

P_and_Q.title: Will the richest person in the world in 2033 have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time AND will we discover clear evidence of proton decay by 2040?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if the richest person in the world in 2033 has a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time AND experimental evidence for proton decay is published in a top peer-reviewed journal prior to 2040. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will human brain emulation be the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if an effort to create a viable (functioning, lasting, sane, etc.) emulated human, based on direct simulation of the neural connectome (and a requisite level of its physical instantiation), succeeds before another form of human-level digital intelligence. The latter will be defined as a digital entity capable of equalling or surpassing most or all core human cognitive capabilities.
If neither a whole human brain emulation nor a human-level digital intelligence has been successfully demonstrated before January 1, 2060, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
*(Edit 10/20/18 to state that it resolves ambiguous rather than negative in the event of no AGI by 2060.)

Q_given_P.title: Given that human brain emulation is the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence, will there be more VR headset sales than AR headset sales in 2025?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if human brain emulation is not the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence. If the condition is met (if human brain emulation is the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence, then resolves YES if the number of virtual reality headsets sold globally in 2025 exceeds the number of augmented reality headsets sold in the same year, and NO if it does not.

P_and_Q.title: Will human brain emulation be the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence AND will there be more VR headset sales than AR headset sales in 2025?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if an effort to create a viable emulated human based on direct simulation of the neural connectome succeeds before another form of human-level digital intelligence AND the number of virtual reality headsets sold globally in 2025 exceeds the number of augmented reality headsets sold in the same year. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will human brain emulation be the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if an effort to create a viable (functioning, lasting, sane, etc.) emulated human, based on direct simulation of the neural connectome (and a requisite level of its physical instantiation), succeeds before another form of human-level digital intelligence. The latter will be defined as a digital entity capable of equalling or surpassing most or all core human cognitive capabilities.
If neither a whole human brain emulation nor a human-level digital intelligence has been successfully demonstrated before January 1, 2060, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
*(Edit 10/20/18 to state that it resolves ambiguous rather than negative in the event of no AGI by 2060.)

Q_given_P.title: Given that human brain emulation is the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence, will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if human brain emulation is not the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence. If human brain emulation is the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence, then resolves YES if the first practical nuclear fusion reactor is developed in China, and NO if it is developed elsewhere.

P_and_Q.title: Will human brain emulation be the first successful route to human-level digital intelligence AND will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if an effort to create a viable emulated human based on direct simulation of the neural connectome succeeds before another form of human-level digital intelligence AND the first practical nuclear fusion reactor is built in China. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will any of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany leave the EU before 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2027, one or more of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany triggers Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon by notifying the European Council of its intention to leave the union.
It also resolves as positive if by the same deadline the entity called European Union has dissolved completely or dissolved to create a new politico-economic union of some European nations under a different name

Q_given_P.title: Given that before 2027, any of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany leave the EU, will Metaculus exist in 2030?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if none of the mentioned countries leave the EU before 2027. If any of the countries trigger Article 50 or the EU dissolves before 2027, then resolves YES if Metaculus exists in 2030 with continuity and NO if it does not.

P_and_Q.title: Will any of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany leave the EU before 2027 AND will Metaculus exist in 2030?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if before January 1, 2027, one or more of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany triggers Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon OR the European Union dissolves completely or dissolves to create a new politico-economic union of some European nations under a different name AND a positive resolution for Metaculus in 2030 requires a degree of continuity with the current version where no more than 1% of all predictions ever made may have been lost from players' point calculating process and no more than one percent of once opened questions may have been lost. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will a sample of negative energy be produced by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Warp drives. Wormholes. Time machines. These exotic structures are the stuff of science fiction, but also have valid mathematical structures behind them in the form of spacetime "metrics" one can write down with the requisite properties.
There is one major physical issue standing in the way actually making them, however: all these possibilities require negative energy.
More specifically, relativists have devised a number of mathematical conditions that may be assumed regarding matter and energy, known as "energy conditions." Wormhole, warp-drive, and time-machine solutions to Einstein's equations essentially always require some substance that violates the "weak energy condition" (WEC), and generally others. Most simply, the WEC states that in the restframe of a material, its energy density is non-negative. (Technically the substance's pressure also must be sufficiently non-negative; see e.g. here for a brief description, and a good relativity text like this one for more gory detail, and here for a recent, interesting review.)
These energy conditions are generically violated at the quantum level, because quantum mechanics entails uncertainty in the energy of a system over a very short time period, so must allow very brief negative-energy fluctuations. But macroscopic amounts of negative energy do not appear possible with any particles or fields we know to exist.
On the other hand, it is somewhat unclear what fundamentally forbids negative energy. Negative energy particles would be bad news, as they would likely render low-energy particles unstable to decay into positive and negative energy ones – such a universe would not last long. But could we devise some strange substance that has the property, using something like the Casimir effect, that takes empty space and removes some energy from it? It sees plausible that negative energy is closely related to violations of the second law of thermodynamics, which would mean that it is very, very hard to violate. But maybe not impossible. "Violations" of the second law (downward movements in entropy) can happen if you wait long enough, or if you set up very, very careful initial conditions (see, e.g. here) So it does not seem impossible that with a high level of tuning a sample of negative energy could be made, though the author is not at all clear how...
So instead we ask:
Will a sample of negative energy material be created by the year 2100?
To be specific, we'll ask whether > 10 proton masses worth of negative energy will be created and confined to a volume of less than 1 cubic centimeter for longer than 1 microsecond, in such a way that during that microsecond there exists a volume of space that could be considered to have a mass of less than -10 proton masses. (As of 2017, the record for antimatter, an altogether easier substance to make, was about 300 proton masses.)

Q_given_P.title: Given that by the year 2100 a sample of negative energy material will be created, will we discover clear evidence of proton decay by 2040?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if a sample of negative energy material is not created by the year 2100. If the condition is met (if a sample of negative energy material is created by 2100), then resolves YES if experimental evidence for proton decay is published in a top peer-reviewed journal prior to 2040, and NO if not.

P_and_Q.title: Will a sample of negative energy be created by 2100 AND will we discover clear evidence of proton decay by 2040?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if > 10 proton masses worth of negative energy will be created and confined to a volume of less than 1 cubic centimeter for longer than 1 microsecond by 2100 AND experimental evidence for proton decay is published in a top peer-reviewed journal prior to 2040. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as positive if by November 30, 2027, a peer-reviewed publication announces the results of such an event. Statistical significance should be at the 4-sigma or equivalent level.
*(edit 1/1017) November 30 is now a publication date rather than data cutoff date.

Q_given_P.title: Given that gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes will be detected by November 30, 2027, will Europa be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the detection of gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes is not announced by November 30, 2027. If the condition is met (if the detection is announced by Nov 30, 2027), then resolves YES if humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045, and does so before detecting extraterrestrial life elsewhere in the universe. Resolves NO if extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa. Resolves Annulled if no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045.

P_and_Q.title: Will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027 AND will Europa be the first place humanity discovers extraterrestrial life if it is discovered before 2045?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if by November 30, 2027, a peer-reviewed publication announces the results of the detection of gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes AND humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extraterrestrial life elsewhere in the universe. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030.
Fine Print
The EU has updated its goals under the Paris Agreement, but this question will use the original goals in place at the time the question was written, specifically the three below.
40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, compared to 2019
At least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy
At least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections

Q_given_P.title: Given that the European Union meets its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty, will a sample of negative energy be produced by 2100?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the European Union does not meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty. If the condition is met (if the EU meets its 2030 targets, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030), then resolves YES if a sample of negative energy material will be created by the year 2100 as specified in the question about negative energy production.

P_and_Q.title: Will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty AND will a sample of negative energy be produced by 2100?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if a credible news report confirms that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals AND if a sample of negative energy material exceeding 10 proton masses is created and confined to a volume of less than 1 cubic centimeter for longer than 1 microsecond by the year 2100. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will we detect a message originating from Luyten's Star before 2046?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as positive if a signal of unambiguously intelligent and extraterrestrial origin originating from Luyten's Star is detected on or near Earth on or before December 31, 2045

Q_given_P.title: Given that a message originating from Luyten's Star is detected before 2046, will there be a Vegan Country by 2100?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if no message is detected from Luyten's Star before 2046. If the condition is met (if a message is detected from Luyten's Star before 2046), then resolves YES if there will be a Vegan Country by 2100 as defined in the question criteria, and NO if there won't be.

P_and_Q.title: Will we detect a message from Luyten's Star before 2046 AND will there be a Vegan Country by 2100?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if a signal of unambiguously intelligent and extraterrestrial origin originating from Luyten's Star is detected on or near Earth on or before December 31, 2045 AND there is a country that bans the consumption of all animal products by 2100. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if one of the 9 nations known to possess nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 (U.S., China, Russia, U.K., France, Israel, India, Pakistan, or North Korea) is certified by the International Atomic Energy Agency to have dismantled all nuclear devices and signs the 2017 UN ban on nuclear weapons on or before January 1, 2035.
Fine Print
For the purposes of this question, in the case of territorial disputes or challenges to a government's legitimacy, successor governments will be recognized as those which hold over 50% of the nation's de facto controlled territory on July 1, 2017. The successor government must also hold a political capital city within that same territory. If any of the 9 countries no longer exist or have no succesor as defined by January 1, 2035, they will be ignored for the resolution of the question.

Q_given_P.title: Given that any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 gives them up before 2035, will Puerto Rico become a US state prior to 2035?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if none of the 9 nations known to possess nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give up their nuclear weapons before 2035. If the condition is met (if any of the 9 nations give up their nuclear weapons before 2035), then resolves YES if Puerto Rico becomes a US state before 2035 and NO if it doesn't.

P_and_Q.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up AND will Puerto Rico become a US state prior to 2035?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if one of the 9 nations known to possess nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 gives up nuclear weapons AND Puerto Rico is admitted as a United States state before January 1, 2035. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will a sample of negative energy be produced by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Warp drives. Wormholes. Time machines. These exotic structures are the stuff of science fiction, but also have valid mathematical structures behind them in the form of spacetime "metrics" one can write down with the requisite properties.
There is one major physical issue standing in the way actually making them, however: all these possibilities require negative energy.

Wormhole, warp-drive, and time-machine solutions to Einstein's equations essentially always require some substance that violates the "weak energy condition" (WEC), and generally others. These energy conditions are generically violated at the quantum level, because quantum mechanics entails uncertainty in the energy of a system over a very short time period, so must allow very brief negative-energy fluctuations. But macroscopic amounts of negative energy do not appear possible with any particles or fields we know to exist.
On the other hand, it is somewhat unclear what fundamentally forbids negative energy. Negative energy particles would be bad news, as they would likely render low-energy particles unstable to decay into positive and negative energy ones – such a universe would not last long. But could we devise some strange substance that has the property, using something like the Casimir effect, that takes empty space and removes some energy from it? It sees plausible that negative energy is closely related to violations of the second law of thermodynamics, which would mean that it is very, very hard to violate. But maybe not impossible. "Violations" of the second law (downward movements in entropy) can happen if you wait long enough, or if you set up very, very careful initial conditions (see, e.g. here) So it does not seem impossible that with a high level of tuning a sample of negative energy could be made, though the author is not at all clear how...
So instead we ask:
Will a sample of negative energy material be created by the year 2100?
To be specific, we'll ask whether > 10 proton masses worth of negative energy will be created and confined to a volume of less than 1 cubic centimeter for longer than 1 microsecond, in such a way that during that microsecond there exists a volume of space that could be considered to have a mass of less than -10 proton masses. (As of 2017, the record for antimatter, an altogether easier substance to make, was about 300 proton masses.)

Q_given_P.title: Given that a sample of negative energy material will be created by the year 2100, will there be a Vegan Country by the same year?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if a sample of negative energy material is not created by the year 2100. If the condition is met (if a sample of negative energy material is created by the year 2100), then resolves YES if there will be a Vegan Country by the same year and NO if there won't be.

P_and_Q.title: Will a sample of negative energy material be created by 2100 AND will there be a Vegan Country by 2100?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if > 10 proton masses worth of negative energy will be created and confined to a volume of less than 1 cubic centimeter for longer than 1 microsecond by 2100 AND there will be a country that bans the consumption of all animal products by 2100. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data

Q_given_P.title: Given that there will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100, will we detect a message originating from Luyten's Star before 2046?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if there is not at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100. If the condition is met (if there is at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100), then resolves YES if a signal of unambiguously intelligent and extraterrestrial origin originating from Luyten's Star is detected on or near Earth on or before December 31, 2045, and NO if it's not detected by then.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100 AND will we detect a message originating from Luyten's Star before 2046?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years with the average global temperature at least 2.0 ˚C greater than in 1880 AND a signal of unambiguously intelligent and extraterrestrial origin from Luyten's Star is detected on or near Earth on or before December 31, 2045. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will SpaceX land people on Mars before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a SpaceX-branded mission successfully lands one or more living human beings on the surface of Mars before 2030. The landing itself of the human crew on Mars must occur before January 1, 2030, 00:00 UTC.
At least one person aboard the lander must survive the landing, however it is not necessary for the person to survive long-term or make a return trip to Earth, nor is it necessary for the mission to intend a return or long-term survival.
A "SpaceX-branded" mission is defined to mean that the SpaceX-associated logos on the spacecraft involved (both the boosters and the Mars-bound craft) have a larger surface area than the logos of any other entity

Q_given_P.title: Given that SpaceX lands people on Mars before 2030, will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if SpaceX does not land people on Mars before 2030. If the condition is met (if SpaceX lands people on Mars before 2030), then resolves YES if there will be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040 based on the described criteria, and NO if not.

P_and_Q.title: Will SpaceX land people on Mars before 2030 AND will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if a SpaceX-branded mission successfully lands one or more living human beings on the surface of Mars before 2030 AND the machine system outscores at least two of the three humans on the specified test prior to 2040. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will RoboCup announce that robots have beaten professional human soccer players before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the RoboCup organization announces that its ultimate goal for robotic soccer has been accomplished before January 1, 2050.
Fine Print
If the RoboCup organization or a clear successor organization ceases to exist this question will be Annulled.
This question defers to announcements by the RoboCup organization, the rules and language regarding their ultimate goal may change so long as it refers to robots winning a game of soccer against professional human soccer players.
If the RoboCup organization still exists at the time of resolution and has not announced that its ultimate goal has been accomplished as described this question will resolve as No.
This question was updated on 16 November 2023 to clarify that a qualifying event must be a game of soccer played by professional human soccer players against robots.
This question was updated on 28 March 2023 to clarify some ambiguities and provide better context. The question text prior to this update is below:
Title: Robocup Challenge Win before 2050?
The Robocup Challenge was launched in the mid-1990s as a "grand challenge" in robotics. The stated goal of the challenge is:
By the middle of the 21st century, a team of fully autonomous humanoid robot soccer players shall win a soccer game, complying with the official rules of FIFA, against the winner of the most recent World Cup.
On the road to this challenge, annual Robocup games are played; see here for upcoming events.
Will Robots win the Robocup challenge, beating professional soccer players before 2050?
This question will resolve as Yes if a team of humanoid robots wins a professional match of soccer before January 1, 2050, as determined by the Robocup challenge organization.

Q_given_P.title: Given that before 2050, RoboCup announces that robots have beaten professional human soccer players, will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the condition regarding RoboCup is not met before 2050. If the condition is met (RoboCup announces robots beating professional human soccer players before 2050), then resolves YES if the first practical nuclear fusion reactor is developed in China and NO if it is developed elsewhere before 2050.

P_and_Q.title: Will RoboCup announce robots beating professional human soccer players AND a practical nuclear fusion reactor be developed in China before 2050?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if the RoboCup organization announces that robots have beaten professional human soccer players AND a practical nuclear fusion reactor is first developed in China before January 1, 2050. Resolves NO otherwise.
